--- title: "3.3 — The Static Benefits of Markets: Welfare Economics & Market Failure — Class Content" execute: freeze: auto --- ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"} # Meeting Date *Wednesday, April 12, 2023* ::: ## Overview Today we consider how markets work and why (and when) they are so efficient at allocating resources and solving social problems. We take a crack at defining efficiency in a few ways: [allocative](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allocative_efficiency), [productive](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Productive_efficiency), [Pareto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pareto_efficiency), and [Kaldor-Hicks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kaldor%E2%80%93Hicks_efficiency) efficiency. We then discuss [Welfare Economics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Welfare_economics) and I summarize three conditions about when markets are good & efficient: 1. Markets are competitive 2. Markets reach equilibrium 3. Markets do not have externalities This leads us into a discussion of [market failure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Market_failure), when markets *aren’t* efficient because something prevents the price system from working properly. We talk about several types of market failures: collective action problems, public goods, and externalities. ## Readings - Ch. 14.2-14.7, Ch. 16 in Goolsbee, Levitt, and Syverson, 2019 Your textbook does cover efficiency and welfare economics in Chapter 14, in the context of general equilibrium theory, which is a bit too advanced for us to spend sufficient time to cover. Thus, I would not recommend reading that chapter unless you are prepared to dive into new tools (Edgeworth diagrams, production possibilities frontiers) that I will not cover in this course. Chapter 16, however, is a pretty accessible discussion of externalities and public goods. ### Optional/Recommended Reading - [ Safner, 2020, "'Public Good,' or 'Good for the Public?' Political Entrepreneurship and the Public Funding of Scientific Research"](https://ryansafner.com/publication/public-good-or-good-for-the-public/) - [ Safner, 2016, "Institutional Entrepreneurship, Wikipedia, and the Opportunity of the Commons"](https://ryansafner.com/publication/institutional-entrepreneurship-wikipedia-and-the-opportunity-of-the-commons/) - [ *Freakonomics Radio* ep. 115: "Parking is Hell"](https://freakonomics.com/podcast/parking-is-hell-a-new-freakonomics-radio-podcast/) - [ MR University: "Trading Pollution: How Pollution Permits Paradoxically Reduce Emissions"](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9tUb3MDrgEc) - [ MR University: "Externalities and Incentives: The Economics of COVID (Vaccines)"](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2EFG6dvtQ6M) - [ *The Lorax* (Dr. Seuss: "How Bad Can I Be?"](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W_HUdf89hI8) - [ *NPR*: "The Nobel Laureate Who Figured Out How To Deal With Annoying People"](https://www.npr.org/sections/money/2013/09/10/218526472/the-nobel-prizewinner-who-figured-out-how-to-deal-with-annoying-people) - [ MR University: "Women in Economics: Elinor Ostrom"](https://learn.mru.org/women-economics-series-elinor-ostrom/) (solving tragedy of the commons)^[Elinor Ostrom was the first woman to win an Economics Nobel prize. She was famous for her work in studying how good rules can prevent a tragedy of the commons for all sorts of common resources such as fisheries, forests, water, and other environmental resources.] - [ Iannaconne, 1992, "Sacrifice and Stigma: Reducing Free-riding in Cults, Communes, and Other Collectives"](/readings/Iannaconne-1992.pdf) - [ *Econtalk*: Iannaconne on the Economics of Religion](https://www.econtalk.org/the-economics-of-religion/) The following Wikipedia entries can also provide more background on today’s concepts (which are well known and standard among economists): ### On Efficiency & Welfare: - [ Allocative efficiency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allocative_efficiency) - [ Productive efficiency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Productive_efficiency) - [ Pareto efficiency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pareto_efficiency) - [ Kaldor-Hicks efficiency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kaldor-Hicks_efficiency) - [ Eminent domain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eminent_domain) - [ Welfare economics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Welfare_economics) ### On Market Failures (and their Solutions): - [ Market Failure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Market_failure) - [ Public good](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_good_(economics)) - [ Externality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Externality) - [ Tragedy of the Commons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tragedy_of_the_Commons) - [ *The Logic of Collective Action*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Logic_of_Collective_Action) - [ Coase Theorem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coase_theorem) ## Slides Below, you can find the slides in two formats. Clicking the image will bring you to the html version of the slides in a new tab.
